card.title: Bread and Circuses (@breadandcircuses@climatejustice.social)
card.description:
Attached: 1 image

Johan Rockström is an internationally recognized scientist who leads development of the planetary boundaries framework, first published in 2009 and updated in 2015 and 2023. (See https://www.stockholmresilience.org/research/planetary-boundaries.html)

Last month, Rockström gave an important talk on “The Tipping Points of Climate Change.” He began his presentation with these ominous words…
_______________________________

We Earth system scientists and climate scientists are getting seriously nervous. The planet is changing faster than we expected. We are, despite years of raising the alarm, now seeing that the planet is actually in a situation where we underestimated risks. Abrupt changes are occurring in a way that is far beyond the realistic expectations in science. 

What worries us most is this: we are starting to see an *acceleration* of warming over the past 50 years. It was 0.18 degrees Celsius per decade from 1970 to 2010, but then from 2014 onwards, it abruptly jumps up to 0.26 per decade. 

If we follow this path, we will crash through two degrees Celsius within 20 years and hit three degrees Celsius by the year 2100, a disastrous outcome.
_______________________________

In the images below (slides from the talk), you can plainly see the acceleration of warming that has Rockström and other scientists so worried.

I’ll post more from this talk in a few minutes. 🧵1/4

FULL PRESENTATION ▶️ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vl6VhCAeEfQ

#Science #Environment #Climate #ClimateChange #ClimateCrisis
card.image_description:
Two graphs, one above the other. Top graph shows annual global mean temperature anomalies from 1850 through 2023. The anomaly in 2023 was 1.45°C, the highest ever recorded.

Bottom graph is the same as the previous one, but this time annotating the global warming acceleration over the past few decades as described in post.

descendants.content: @RichardAshwell Depends on how you define "tipping points." The GCMs model the dynamics of the atmosphere and how they will respond to increased GHG concentrations, but all possible (but unknown) dynamic changes and nonlinear impacts are not included

descendants.content:
@petergleick @RichardAshwell

yeah, there are so many unknowns, still.

researchers just published about methane that is coming out grassy areas that were not expected to be a source of methane. surprise!
& some of those places contain things called taliks, which hold a lot of carbon in permafrost, which is thawing.

"Contrary to current climate model predictions, these findings imply a positive and much larger permafrost-methane-climate feedback for upland Yedoma."

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-024-50346-5

card.title: Upland Yedoma taliks are an unpredicted source of atmospheric methane - Nature Communications
card.description: Contrary to current model predictions, this study shows that rapid permafrost thaw in well drained uplands leads to exceedingly high methane emissions ( ~ 10-60 times higher than expected) from deeply-thawed yedoma soils, particularly in winter.

descendants.content:
@RichardAshwell @petergleick the current consensus is that there is a near linear relationship between CO2 and climate change. There are a variety of feedback loops at play, but no singular tipping point

Of course we don't know this for certain and there is a chance scientists are wrong, but that's the consensus among the people who know best at the moment

IPCC source, page 28: https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg1/downloads/report/IPCC_AR6_WGI_SPM.pdf

descendants.content:
@petergleick
That red part of the graph isn't valid past about 2050 because "business as usual" simply doesn't exist under those conditions and nobody knows what would happen.

It's overly optimistic just to have it sitting there looking like an actual projection we can reason about.

The diagram should have a big red line on it labelled "probably everyone is dead" but I'm not sure where. We should be more concerned that we don't know where that line is.
